Hi Colin,

	Another take on this is something I've pondered about for GP, and which is 
inspired by nature.  In nature, not all parts of a chromosome exhibit equal 
mutation rates.  Now this is not clean data, because when we look at 
chromosomes we are always seeing them after _some_ degree of selection, but 
even so it is thought that genes can evolve higher or lower mutation 
rates.  There is a technique which uses this for GA (*).  Basically what it 
does is that on each "gene" (which are single real values) it stores a 
second parameter to control the mutation of the parameter (I think as the 
width of the distribution around the current gene value).  Thus the 
gene-values and the individual gene mutabilities co-evolve - genes which 
cannot vary without losing a lot of fitness acquire low mutabilities 
whereas those which can still vary usefully stay highly mutable.... (ISRT 
this technique lacks any concept of an "elite" so that every gene is 
subject to a mutation in every generation).

	Anyway, one can easily adapt it for NEAT, either as a parameter for 
mutation distribution width, or mutation probability, or both.

	One could even look to the connection probabilities, maybe as an evolving 
parameter read from the destination (being the node most affected by 
connection) or else read from both genes concerned and multiplied together...

	Node creation would then be, I guess, a probability on each connection, 
maybe (waves hands vaguely)...

--

	As an aside, this also gives us another angle on modularity, since a 
useful module should have a net mutability which has dropped quite low, and 
one might also want to allow a quite different value for the probability of 
intra-module connection formation vs. inter-module connection formation...

	Ian

(*) I think it is "Evolution Strategy" (ES).  I checked here 
http://www.cs.bham.ac.uk/Mirrors/ftp.de.uu.net/EC/clife/www/top.htm), but 
it's too heavy for me to (re)comprehend in a short time.
